Minyard Food Stores, Inc. has and will continue to be concerned with all aspects of enviornmental, health, and safety issues.  We have focused our attention and resources towards the protection of our employees, the public, and in particular those areas involving the operation of our warehouse refrigeration system.  We have gone beyond the standard for protection from accidental contact with refrigeration components (ie. placing steel racks/cases around exposed piping and air handling units) and have provided detection equipment at critical component locations for the quick detection and mitigation of materials, in the event of a release.

Minyard Food Stores, Inc. operates a distribution center for the purpose of supplying our retail grocery stores.  Included in our warehousing operations is the cold storage of products.  This portion of the warehouse utilizes anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.  The refrigeration process contains approximately 25,000 pounds of refrigerant.  Simulating a release utilizing the EPA's Risk Management Plan calculations, our release of ammonia in a worst case scenario would result in the potential exposure of an area from the warehouse motor room with a four-tenths of a mile radius.  Contained within that radius are several businesses and approximately four residences.  This scenario would involve the loss of power resulting in the automatic return of ammonia to the main vessel of the three storage vessels; and the subsequent failure of a pressure relief valve causing a release of ammonia.  The mitigation of such a release, would be through early detection and notification of appropriate staff that is capable of assessing the situation remotely and begin the mitigation process (ie. isolating the point of release by valving-off the affected area, recalling the ammonia back to the storage vessels, and/or shutting down the process). Our alternative scenario would involve normal operation of the system, but a failure of a check valve resu

lting in a release.  Such an event would not result in an off-site consequence effect.

This process maintains a quantity of ammonia in excess of the threshold value for this hazardous material, we have complied with OSHA's Process Safety Management Program and EPA's Risk Management Plan.  These programs have afforded us the opportunity to develop prevention and emergency response programs addressing the potential for a release of ammonia.  The Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard for covered facilities requires the implimentation of thirteen elements, which are listed and summerized below:

           1.  Employee Participation - active involvement of employees in the development and implimentation of
                the Process Safety Management Program.
           2.  Process Safety Information - having and making available to employees information pertaining to
                the process, hazardous material data, and diagraming.
           3.  Process Hazard Analysis - analysis of hazards associated with the process and recommen-
                dation for risk reduction.
           4.  Operating Procedures - written procedures for normal operations, routine maintenance, special
                operations and emergency response.
           5.  Training - requirements for training based upon position and response.
           6.  Contractor Requirements - qualifications to meet for contractors to meet  for conducting of any
                construction or maintenance operations on or around the process.
           7.  Pre-Startup Safety Review - check and balance of systems to review prior to the startup of the
                process.
           8.  Mechanical Integrity Audits - written procedures to verify the integrity of process equipment.
           9.  Hot Work Permits - written procedures developed to prevent fires from cutting, welding, or
                brazing work conducted inside a facility.
         10.  Management of Change - procedures develop

ed to assure that changes to the process are 
                implemented safely.
         11.  Incident Investigation - written procedures for the investigation, documentation, and follow-up for
                recommendations as the result of a loss involving a hazardous material.
         12.  Emergency Planning and Response - procedures developed for guidance on our reaction to a
                release of ammonia.
         13.  Compliance Audits - procedures to document the compliance with the provisions of the Reg-
                ulation.

The Risk Management Plan's (RMP) purpose is to identify the potential ramifications to the public as a result of an ammonia release; to work with local, state, and federal agencies should a release occur, so as to minimize the impact of a release; and to remove those who may be in harms way as a result of a release of a hazardous material.  RMP's contain nine (9) elements which are summerized below:

          1.  The chemicals name and make-up.
          2.  The physical state of the chemical.
          3.  Senario's, both worst case and alternative, regarding the potential impact in the event of such a
               release.
          4.  Quantity of release.
          5.  The release rate and duration.
          6.  Atmospheric conditions and there impact on a release.
          7.  Distances to release endpoints.
          8.  Public and environmental receptors within the release endpoint for notification purposes.
          9.  Release controls and mitigation measures.

We believe the technological inhancements of the process (computer generated evaluation and mitigation controls) along with our procedural and training efforts are keys to the prevention and reduction of con-
sequences to the enviroment and public.

Our process is classified as a Single Stationary Source, with a Program Level 3 Compliance Status, and has not incurred a loss/release that had any off-site consequence or exposure to the enviroment since i

ts construction five years ago.  There have been two slight releases, within the warehouse, resulting in the momentary evacuation of employees from the immediate area with no injuries or consequences.

Minyard Food Stores has worked with the City of Coppell Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee, as well as with hired outside consultants in the development of and coordination of an emergency response in the event of an ammonia release.  We are in constant review of our operations and consider any new technology, control equipment, and training that will improve our margin of safety and prevent the accidental release of ammonia to the enviroment.
